Award.AbstractNarration:
This project consists of theoretical research dealing with semi-inclusive and exclusive scattering processes in the region of intermediate to high energies, with a particular emphasis on polarization phenomena. The study of such reactions has attracted considerable interest during recent years as they allow one to explore for the first time the three-dimensional parton structure of the nucleon, and to investigate a set of new, intriguing, and nontrivial questions related to perturbative quantum chromodynamics (QCD). The research program mainly addresses two key topics: first, new ways for exploring the underlying physics of single spin phenomena in high energy processes will be outlined. Second, it will be studied in detail how the three-dimensional gluon structure of the nucleon, both in momentum space and in position space, can be deciphered. In order to carry out this program a number of conceptual model-independent investigations as well as numerical/phenomenological studies will be used. The project is directly related to ongoing and planned measurements in lepton hadron collisions at the Jefferson Laboratory (JLab) in Newport News, VA, and in proton proton collisions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) in Brookhaven, NY. In the future, a potential new Electron Ion Collider (EIC) will also address this physics.

These activities will help us to better understand the structure of protons and neutrons at unprecedented levels of detail and with new ways of visualizing the scientific basis for that understanding. Graduate students will be involved in this very active field at the frontier of current hadronic physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a continuation of theoretical research dealing with semi-inclusive and exclusive scattering processes in the region of intermediate to high energies. The study of such reactions has attracted considerable interest during recent years as they allow one to explore for the first time the 3-dimensional parton (quark and gluon) structure of strongly interacting systems, and to investigate a set of new, intriguing, and nontrivial questions related to perturbative Quantum Chromodynamics (QCD).

Related measurements in lepton-hadron collisions have been performed at the Jefferson Laboratory (JLab) in Newport News (Virginia) --- home of CEBAF, a continuous beam electron accelerator whose energy has just been upgraded to 12 GeV --- and at other laboratories around the world. Experiments in proton-proton scattering, with center-of-mass energies up to 500 GeV, are performed at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) in Brookhaven (New York). In the future, a potential new Electron Ion Collider (EIC) will also address this physics.

The intellectual merit of the project, for the entire 3-year period, has been documented in 11 articles published in peer-reviewed journals, a omprehensive White Paper on the EIC with contribution from the PI, and a considerable number of talks and conference proceedings by the PI as well as his collaborators.

We want to briefly describe two important outcomes of the project. The first one deals with the large (up to 40%) transverse single-spin asymmetries (SSAs) observed in reactions like single-inclusive hadron production in proton-proton collisions, pp -> hX. Since quite some time it is generally believed that collinear twist-3 factorization is the most appropriate QCD framework for such observables, where the majority of the community considered the twist-3 effect associated with the (transversely polarized) target to be dominant. However, this assumption gave rise to the so-called "sign-mismatch" puzzle when trying to relate SSAs in hadronic collisions to those in lepton-nucleon scattering. Therefore we have studied in detail the long ignored twist-3 parton fragmentation effect. We obtained the analytical result for this contribution and a good numerical description of the transverse SSAs measured at RHIC. Though further cross checks are needed, we may well have finally found what causes those intriguing observables in QCD. The aforementioned sign-mismatch problem is also solved when taking into account the contributiion from parton frgamentation. 

The second outcome addresses the famous spin sum rule of the nucleon, i.e., the decomposition of the nucleon spin into spin and orbital angular momentum from quarks and gluons. It is known for a long time that the quark spin makes up a much smaller fraction (about 30%) of the nucleon spin-1/2 than originally thought. Even though there is now indication from recent RHIC measurements of a nonzero gluon spin contribution, a lot of room remains for orbital angular momentum of partons. The most intuitive definition of parton orbital angular momentum is based on generalized transverse momentum dependent parton distributions (GTMDs). Those objects describe the most general partonic structure of strongly interacting systems like the nucleon. Several GTMDs reduce to TMDs or GPDs ---- parton distributions that describe the 3-dimensional structure of hadrons in momentum space or in position space, respectively. A recent work had put into question the parameterization of GTMDs for a spin-1/2 hadron. In particular, the mere existence of the GTMDs that give access to parton orbital angular momentum was doubted.
